Read on to learn more about what keratosis pilaris is, what causes it, and how to treat it using natural remedies that are gentle and effective. What Is Keratosis Pilaris? Keratosis pilaris is a common [skin condition](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/general-health/anti-aging/common-skin-conditions/) that is characterized by small, rough bumps on the skin, usually on the arms, thighs, and buttocks. The bumps resemble goosebumps or the skin of a plucked chicken. This is how the condition gets its nickname of "chicken skin." They can also look like small [pimples](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/general-health/energy-and-immunity/back-acne/). The bumps are usually harmless and do not [itch](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/general-health/energy-and-immunity/whats-causing-your-itchy-scalp/) or burn. They typically feel rough to the touch and are made of plugs of dead skin cells. What Causes Keratosis Pilaris? Keratosis pilaris is caused by the overproduction of keratin. This can block the hair follicles and lead to the formation of bumps. Keratosis Pilaris vs. Eczema: What's The Difference? [Eczema](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/general-health/energy-and-immunity/eczema-treatment/) is a term used to describe a group of inflammatory skin conditions that cause red, itchy, and inflamed skin. It is often triggered by environmental factors, such as dry skin, irritants, or allergies. However, it can also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as dryness, redness, itching, and flakiness. "According to TCM, keratosis pilaris and eczema are not necessarily treated differently. Both conditions may be classified as skin disorders that involve inflammation and excess keratin production," stated Physician Goh. Diet and nutrition TCM practitioners may recommend dietary modifications to help improve the health of the skin, such as increasing the intake of nourishing and moistening foods, and reducing the intake of drying (Heaty) and irritating (flared up) foods. Physician Goh recommends that you try to avoid the food below: - Refined Food: , cakes, bread, cookies, ice cream, and chocolate [Sugar](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/pregnancy-and-childrens-health/childrens-health/refined-sugar/) - Meat: Beef and lamb - Seafood: Prawn, crab, and shellfish - Dairy: Milk, cheese, and cream - Spices: , garlic, and pepper [Ginger](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/glossary/zingiber-dried-ginger/) Tips For Managing Keratosis Pilaris TCM practitioners may recommend lifestyle changes to help improve the health of the skin, such as reducing [stress](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/general-health/energy-and-immunity/stress-balls-and-baoding-balls/), [getting enough sleep](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/mental-health/sleep/sleep-deprivation/), and practicing [proper skin care](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/general-health/anti-aging/skin-care/). Here are some tips Physician Goh recommends: - Moisturize regularly. Keeping the skin well-moisturized can help reduce the appearance of bumps and roughness. Look for a moisturizer that contains urea, lactic acid, or alpha-hydroxy acid, which can help soften and exfoliate the skin. - Use [gentle skincare products](https://www.euyansang.com/en_US/adult-calming-relief-set-GA24096X.html). Avoid using harsh soaps or cleansers that can strip the skin of its natural oils. Instead, opt for gentle, fragrance-free products that won't irritate the skin. - Exfoliate gently. Gently exfoliating the skin can help remove dead skin cells and unclog pores. Avoid using harsh, abrasive scrubs, and instead, opt for a gentle exfoliator or a loofah or sponge to gently slough off dead skin cells. - Avoid [hot showers](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/general-health/energy-and-immunity/cold-shower-benefits/). Hot water can strip the skin of its natural oils, which can exacerbate dryness and irritation. Try taking lukewarm showers instead. - Protect your skin from the sun. [Sun exposure](https://www.allthingshealth.com/en-us/general-health/energy-and-immunity/sun-poisoning/)can dry out the skin and worsen keratosis pilaris. Be sure to use a broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher to protect your skin from harmful UV rays. - Stay hydrated. Drinking plenty of water can help keep your skin hydrated and healthy. Aim to drink at least 8-8 ounces of water per day. - Avoid tight clothing. Tight clothing can irritate the skin and worsen keratosis pilaris. Wear loose, comfortable clothing to allow your skin to breathe. - Use humidifiers. Dry air can worsen keratosis pilaris, so using a humidifier can help keep your skin moisturized. - Avoid picking at the bumps. Picking at the bumps can cause irritation and inflammation, which can worsen the condition. Try to resist the temptation to pick at the bumps and let them heal on their own.
